metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: XSD Indicators
We can control HOW elements are to be used in documents with indicators.
content.html: We can control HOW elements are to be used in documents with indicators.

content.text: Indicators
There are seven indicators:
content.html: There are seven indicators:

content.text: Order indicators:
content.html: Order indicators:

content.text: Occurrence indicators:
content.html: Occurrence indicators:

content.text: Group indicators:
content.html: Group indicators:

content.text: Order Indicators
Order indicators are used to define the order of the elements.
content.html: Order indicators are used to define the order of the elements.

content.text: All Indicator
The <all> indicator specifies that the child elements can appear in any order, and that each child element must occur only once:
content.html: The <all> indicator specifies that the child elements can appear in any order, and that each child element must occur only once:

content.code_html:
<xs:element name="person">
  <xs:complexType>
    <xs:all>
      <xs:element name="firstname" type="xs:string"/>
      <xs:element name="lastname" type="xs:string"/>
    </xs:all>
  </xs:complexType>
</xs:element>

content.text: Note: When using the <all> indicator you can set the <minOccurs> indicator to 0 or 1 and the <maxOccurs> indicator can only be set to 1 (the <minOccurs> and <maxOccurs> are described later).
content.html: Note: When using the <all> indicator you can set the <minOccurs> indicator to 0 or 1 and the <maxOccurs> indicator can only be set to 1 (the <minOccurs> and <maxOccurs> are described later).

content.text: Choice Indicator
The <choice> indicator specifies that either one child element or another can occur:
content.html: The <choice> indicator specifies that either one child element or another can occur:

content.code_html:
<xs:element name="person">
  <xs:complexType>
    <xs:choice>
      <xs:element name="employee" type="employee"/>
      <xs:element name="member" type="member"/>
    </xs:choice>
  </xs:complexType>
</xs:element>

content.text: Sequence Indicator
The <sequence> indicator specifies that the child elements must appear in a specific order:
content.html: The <sequence> indicator specifies that the child elements must appear in a specific order:

content.code_html:
<xs:element name="person">
   <xs:complexType>
    <xs:sequence>
      <xs:element name="firstname" type="xs:string"/>
      <xs:element name="lastname" type="xs:string"/>
    </xs:sequence>
  </xs:complexType>
</xs:element>

content.text: Occurrence Indicators
Occurrence indicators are used to define how often an element can occur.
content.html: Occurrence indicators are used to define how often an element can occur.

content.text: Note: For all "Order" and "Group" indicators (any, all, choice, sequence, group name, and group reference) the default value for maxOccurs and minOccurs is 1.
content.html: Note: For all "Order" and "Group" indicators (any, all, choice, sequence, group name, and group reference) the default value for maxOccurs and minOccurs is 1.

content.text: maxOccurs Indicator
The <maxOccurs> indicator specifies the maximum number of times an element can occur:
content.html: The <maxOccurs> indicator specifies the maximum number of times an element can occur:

content.code:
<xs:element name="person">


<xs:complexType>


<xs:sequence>


<xs:element name="full_name" type="xs:string"/>


<xs:element name="child_name" type="xs:string" maxOccurs="10"/>


</xs:sequence>


</xs:complexType>

</xs:element>
content.code_html:
<xs:element name="person">
  <xs:complexType>
    <xs:sequence>
      <xs:element name="full_name" type="xs:string"/>
      <xs:element name="child_name" type="xs:string" maxOccurs="10"/>
    </xs:sequence>
  </xs:complexType>
</xs:element>

content.text: The example above indicates that the "child_name" element can occur a minimum of one time (the default value for minOccurs is 1) and a maximum of ten times in the "person" element.
content.html: The example above indicates that the "child_name" element can occur a minimum of one time (the default value for minOccurs is 1) and a maximum of ten times in the "person" element.

content.text: minOccurs Indicator
The <minOccurs> indicator specifies the minimum number of times an element can occur:
content.html: The <minOccurs> indicator specifies the minimum number of times an element can occur:

content.code:
<xs:element name="person">


<xs:complexType>


<xs:sequence>


<xs:element name="full_name" type="xs:string"/>


<xs:element name="child_name" type="xs:string"

maxOccurs="10" minOccurs="0"/>


</xs:sequence>


</xs:complexType>

</xs:element>
content.code_html:
<xs:element name="person">
  <xs:complexType>
    <xs:sequence>
      <xs:element name="full_name" type="xs:string"/>
      <xs:element name="child_name" type="xs:string"
      maxOccurs="10" minOccurs="0"/>
    </xs:sequence>
  </xs:complexType>
</xs:element>

content.text: The example above indicates that the "child_name" element can occur a minimum of zero times and a maximum of ten times in the "person" element.
content.html: The example above indicates that the "child_name" element can occur a minimum of zero times and a maximum of ten times in the "person" element.

content.text: Tip: To allow an element to appear an unlimited number of times, use the maxOccurs="unbounded" statement:
content.html: Tip: To allow an element to appear an unlimited number of times, use the maxOccurs="unbounded" statement:

content.text: A working example:
content.html: A working example:

content.text: An XML file called "Myfamily.xml":
content.html: An XML file called "Myfamily.xml":

content.code_html:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<persons xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="family.xsd">

<person>
  <full_name>Hege Refsnes</full_name>
  <child_name>Cecilie</child_name>
</person>

<person>
  <full_name>Tove Refsnes</full_name>
  <child_name>Hege</child_name>
  <child_name>Stale</child_name>
  <child_name>Jim</child_name>
  <child_name>Borge</child_name>
</person>

<person>
  <full_name>Stale Refsnes</full_name>
</person>

</persons>

content.text: The XML file above contains a root element named "persons". Inside this root element we have defined three "person" elements. Each "person" element must contain a "full_name" element and it can contain up to five "child_name" elements.
content.html: The XML file above contains a root element named "persons". Inside this root element we have defined three "person" elements. Each "person" element must contain a "full_name" element and it can contain up to five "child_name" elements.

content.text: Here is the schema file "family.xsd":
content.html: Here is the schema file "family.xsd":

content.code:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<xs:schema xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"
elementFormDefault="qualified">


<xs:element name="persons">


<xs:complexType>


<xs:sequence>


<xs:element name="person" maxOccurs="unbounded">


<xs:complexType>


<xs:sequence>


<xs:element name="full_name" type="xs:string"/>


<xs:element name="child_name" type="xs:string"

minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="5"/>


</xs:sequence>


</xs:complexType>


</xs:element>


</xs:sequence>


</xs:complexType>

</xs:element>


</xs:schema>
content.code_html:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<xs:schema xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"
elementFormDefault="qualified">

<xs:element name="persons">
  <xs:complexType>
    <xs:sequence>
      <xs:element name="person" maxOccurs="unbounded">
        <xs:complexType>
          <xs:sequence>
            <xs:element name="full_name" type="xs:string"/>
            <xs:element name="child_name" type="xs:string"
            minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="5"/>
          </xs:sequence>
        </xs:complexType>
      </xs:element>
    </xs:sequence>
  </xs:complexType>
</xs:element>

</xs:schema>

content.text: Group Indicators
Group indicators are used to define related sets of elements.
content.html: Group indicators are used to define related sets of elements.

content.text: Element Groups
Element groups are defined with the group declaration, like this:
content.html: Element groups are defined with the group declaration, like this:

content.code_html:
<xs:group name="groupname">
...
</xs:group>

content.text: You must define an all, choice, or sequence element inside the group declaration. The following example defines a group named "persongroup", that defines a group of elements that must occur in an exact sequence:
content.html: You must define an all, choice, or sequence element inside the group declaration. The following example defines a group named "persongroup", that defines a group of elements that must occur in an exact sequence:

content.code:
<xs:group name="persongroup">


<xs:sequence>


<xs:element name="firstname" type="xs:string"/>


<xs:element name="lastname" type="xs:string"/>


<xs:element name="birthday" type="xs:date"/>


</xs:sequence>

</xs:group>
content.code_html:
<xs:group name="persongroup">
  <xs:sequence>
    <xs:element name="firstname" type="xs:string"/>
    <xs:element name="lastname" type="xs:string"/>
    <xs:element name="birthday" type="xs:date"/>
  </xs:sequence>
</xs:group>

content.text: After you have defined a group, you can reference it in another definition, like this:
content.html: After you have defined a group, you can reference it in another definition, like this:

content.code:
<xs:group name="persongroup">


<xs:sequence>


<xs:element name="firstname" type="xs:string"/>


<xs:element name="lastname" type="xs:string"/>


<xs:element name="birthday" type="xs:date"/>


</xs:sequence>

</xs:group>


<xs:element name="person" type="personinfo"/>


<xs:complexType name="personinfo">


<xs:sequence>


<xs:group ref="persongroup"/>


<xs:element name="country" type="xs:string"/>


</xs:sequence>

</xs:complexType>
content.code_html:
<xs:group name="persongroup">
  <xs:sequence>
    <xs:element name="firstname" type="xs:string"/>
    <xs:element name="lastname" type="xs:string"/>
    <xs:element name="birthday" type="xs:date"/>
  </xs:sequence>
</xs:group>

<xs:element name="person" type="personinfo"/>

<xs:complexType name="personinfo">
  <xs:sequence>
    <xs:group ref="persongroup"/>
    <xs:element name="country" type="xs:string"/>
  </xs:sequence>
</xs:complexType>

content.text: Attribute Groups
Attribute groups are defined with the attributeGroup declaration, like this:
content.html: Attribute groups are defined with the attributeGroup declaration, like this:

content.code_html:
<xs:attributeGroup name="groupname">
...
</xs:attributeGroup>

content.text: The following example defines an attribute group named "personattrgroup":
content.html: The following example defines an attribute group named "personattrgroup":

content.code:
<xs:attributeGroup name="personattrgroup">


<xs:attribute name="firstname" type="xs:string"/>


<xs:attribute name="lastname" type="xs:string"/>


<xs:attribute name="birthday" type="xs:date"/>

</xs:attributeGroup>
content.code_html:
<xs:attributeGroup name="personattrgroup">
  <xs:attribute name="firstname" type="xs:string"/>
  <xs:attribute name="lastname" type="xs:string"/>
  <xs:attribute name="birthday" type="xs:date"/>
</xs:attributeGroup>

content.text: After you have defined an attribute group, you can reference it in another definition, like this:
content.html: After you have defined an attribute group, you can reference it in another definition, like this:

content.code:
<xs:attributeGroup name="personattrgroup">


<xs:attribute name="firstname" type="xs:string"/>


<xs:attribute name="lastname" type="xs:string"/>


<xs:attribute name="birthday" type="xs:date"/>

</xs:attributeGroup>


<xs:element name="person">


<xs:complexType>


<xs:attributeGroup ref="personattrgroup"/>


</xs:complexType>

</xs:element>
content.code_html:
<xs:attributeGroup name="personattrgroup">
  <xs:attribute name="firstname" type="xs:string"/>
  <xs:attribute name="lastname" type="xs:string"/>
  <xs:attribute name="birthday" type="xs:date"/>
</xs:attributeGroup>

<xs:element name="person">
  <xs:complexType>
    <xs:attributeGroup ref="personattrgroup"/>
  </xs:complexType>
</xs:element>
